Award.AwardTitle: NCS-FO: Collaborative Research: Developing Underwater EEG Electrodes for Octopus Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The octopus is a social animal, with high intelligence and problem-solving skills, that is very distant from humans in terms of its evolution. This project aims to fabricate neuroelectric sensors and experimental protocols that would enable studying visual and higher level cognitive processes in the octopus while they are engaged in natural behaviors in an underwater environment. This will necessitate development of new engineering solutions for crafting electroencephalography (EEG) sensors that can record signal underwater, new solutions for removing noise artifacts from these highly complicated recordings, as well as careful design of experiments that could study such behaviors in a virtual-reality environment. While the brain of the octopus is very different from that of the human, it does support well-defined cognitive functions. Therefore, understanding whether and how octopuses' brains implement processes such as learning, attention, habituation, and surprise can produce new and important understandings of how neurobiological systems can support function. This research might reveal that the neural substrates of cognitive function in the octopus are organized according to principles that differ drastically from those found in in humans.

This EAGER project has several aims. It will develop the first underwater EEG, first testing well-validated paradigms on humans performing task underwater and benchmarking against known waveforms. The electrodes will be constructed so that they do not corrode in salt water. It will also develop high-quality virtual reality stimulation that could impact octopuses' behavior in an underwater environment. It will utilize EEG frequency-tagging techniques to determine processing of environmental stimulus by the octopus. This will allow studying whether octopuses present characteristic responses that are analogous to surprise, adaptation, working memory and attention effects (in primates and other vertebrates). The study will also allow answering how and in what manner do octopuses sleep. All data, artifacts and modeling software will be made publicly available and constitute an important resource for the community. The results of this study could impact our general understanding of how brains support complex cognitive functions, with direct relevance to artificial intelligence efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This two years of EAGER funding permitted the three team members (Peter Tse of Dartmouth College, Gideon Caplovitz of the University of Nevada at Reno, and Walt Besio of the University of Rhode Island) to focus on the technical development of underwater electrodes intended for electroencephalography (EEG) using octopus bimaculoides. Numerous technical hurdles had to be addressed. It was not practical to place electrodes onto the octopus, so we instead opted to place the octopus onto the electrodes. These lay in a polymer sheet affixed to the bottom of a clear plexiglas box containing seawater, with wire leads leading into and out of the box to our data acquisition system. The electrodes used were modified from the existing tripolar electrodes invented by co-PI Walt Besio of the University of Rhode Island. Because octopuses move a lot, and tended to rip apart our initial attempts at polymer sheets and wires, we developed, through trial and error, a system that constrains their movement while in no way harming them (octopuses generally squeeze into small spaces and peer out). We embedded electrodes into an unrippable polymer sheet affixed to the bottom of a 4" clear cube, and placed an octopus  on top of this sheet, in about an inch of continually refreshed water. Because the water was shallow, the octopus stayed on top of the electrode sheet. We then showed octopuses lights flickering at various frequencies on a screen outside of the cube, but easily visible to the octopus. We were able to pick up the power associated with this flicker frequency in the EEG, and believe this to be associated with visual neural activity from the octopus. We intended to do further electrode and octopus EEG development, but the Covid-19 pandemic shut down all research in the Dartmouth Octopus Cognition Lab starting March 2020, which hampered our ability to continue to refine our electrodes and measure more complex EEG signals from octopuses. However, Walt Besio continued to develop the electrodes and their placement in the box during the pandemic. Once Covid restrictions lift, presumably in the Summer of 2021, we will carry on electrode and EEG development where we left off in March 2020.
